Stephen Hunt.text:
The confusion, at least to me, is that DFS usually doesn't dismiss nodes as unsearchable until they have been visited. In the example above, Z was not yet visited when we were on E, otherwise Z would have been in the "closed nodes" list. Therefore, we should have been able to go to B from E and the search would have returned A B E Z. 
  To add, looking for B and comparing g values within the node queue is more representative of UCS and not DFS. UCS by definition makes queuing decisions based off of g (that's the whole point of it and what separates it from BFS/DFS). DFS only makes queuing decisions based off of parent/child relationship and whether a node has already been visited. So the second part is wondering why we're using g as a decision maker during DFS queuing.

I understand what it says, I just disagree with it. It goes against the implementation principles of DFS -- i.e. "Remove a node only after it has been visited" and "don't consider any costs during the search". Again, Z was not yet visited while we were on E, so we should have still been able to go to it.
Yes, I agree about the loops. I think at this point only the instructors can clarify the confusion.

Combining "this would also be possible without any cost considerations" and "I recommend you just go with what was laid out in the slides because this is what you'll be graded on" is good enough for me. =D

The solution in the slide does give the same solution as BFS would (that happens sometimes), but it is not BFS. Specifically because of the LIFO, as opposed to FIFO, nature of the queue. LIFO = DFS, FIFO = BFS. 
  The loop detection presented in the slides does change the results of the algorithm and in this case makes it give the same solution as a BFS search would, but as the instructor has stated, there are different ways of implementing loop detection. With the different ways of implementing loop detection, it would be best to do it the way the instructors have seeing as that is how the HW will be graded.

  One instructor previously replied on this post " I feel that the 'clean, robust algorithm' shows you what you need to be doing".

The algorithm on slide 113 (session 2-4) says that if a node exists in the open queue with the same state as the child node, and the cost of the new child node is lower that the existing node, then:
1. Delete the node with the same state from the open queue.
2. Add the new child node to the open queue.
  Therefore, I think it should be treated as a new node (choice A).
  It does not say anything about updating the node in the queue.

Sebastian Gomez Velasco.title: A* re-discovering or not nodes in the closed list
Sebastian Gomez Velasco.text:
I've been reading some posts on Piazza asking whether or not (in the realm of HW1) we should add to the open queue a node that IS in the closed list and for which we have found a cheaper path.
  In @114, Daniel Link has stated that: We should use the standard implementation that can be found on Wikipedia or similar sites, because there is no pseudo-code on the slides for A*.
  The problem is that Wikipedia's version of A* assumes a consistent heuristic, and states (in additional notes) that if the heuristic is not consistent, nodes in the closed may be rediscovered and their cost improved (modifying the pseudo code).
  For this, the last answer was that both versions will work.
So, I would like to share this input for A*.
  A*
S
G
7
S A 1
S B 4
A B 2
A C 5
A G 12
B C 2
C G 3
5
S 7
A 6
B 2
C 1
G 0
  When we expand S, we add A and B to the open queue.
B (f = 4 + 2)
A (f = 1 + 6)
  Since B has a lower f, it gets expanded first, and the open queue has:
A (f = 1 + 6)
C (f = 6 + 1)
  Now, A has a lower f, so it gets expanded, and we find a cheaper path to B that is already in the closed.
  To sum up, if we implement A* as defined in Wikipedia (assuming a consistent heuristic), the answer would be:
S(0) -> B(4) -> C(6) -> G(9)
  However, if we implement A* as UCS is described on the slides (a modified version for A*), the answer would be:
S(0) -> A (1) -> B(3) -> C(5) -> G(8)
(that's reaching B from the cheaper path through A)
  Since it was stated that both versions of A* will work, does it mean that:
1. for these cases both solutions will be accepted as correct?
2. no case like this will be tested when grading? Meaning, there will NOT be the case that we find a cheaper path to a node that is already in the closed list.

According to my understanding, the answer is: ACEG
  It's true that you'll have a tie between E, F and D; all with a cost of 5 so far, but applying the tie-breaking rules you get:
  1. E and F have the same parent, so you use the order in which they appear in the input file (E comes first)
2. D got removed from the open queue when it had cost of 6, and inserted again with a new cost of 5 (following the algorithm as specified on the slides), applying the last tie-breaking rule added in the hint section: newly expanded nodes should enqueued after older ones already in the queue, D goes last, after E and F.
  Therefore, the next node to expand is E, setting the path to the goal: ACEG

Agree, but it actually raises the question: which is the correct version for A*? rather than which output is correct for UCS? (since UCS pseudo-code is on the slides)
  So basically, which version is the correct one for A*?
* A version based on UCS? (deleting and inserting nodes)?
* A version that updates the node in the queue?
I agree too, but we need an answer from an instructor.
Thanks! But my question is how to implement A* (see my first post on this discussion)
We created a new discussion here @178 for A*

To elaborate a little more the question. Which version is correct for A*?

* A version based on UCS? (deleting and inserting nodes)?
* A version that updates the existing node rather than creating a new one? (Wikipedia's version, taking into account that Wikipedia's pseudo-code does not use a queue)
  The answer to this question affects how we break ties using the last rule added last week.
    -------
Actually, Wikipedia's version does use a queue, they just don't explicitly mention it as being a queue.

Thanks, but @114 refers to whether or not re-discover nodes that are already in the closed list when we find a cheaper path.
  Here we are asking for the open queue when we find a cheaper path to a node that has not been expanded yet. The question is for A* (for which we don't have the pseudo-code on the slides):
  * Do we remove (the expensive node) and create a new node (the cheap one) to be added to the open queue? (Based on UCS)
* Do we update the node in the queue? (More like Wikipedia's pseudo-code)
  Again, this affects tie-breaking.
  Therefore, it's not a duplicate question.

There was a long discussion today about that since for A* there is no algorithm on the slides. To sum up:
  * Updating the node in the queue -> Wikipedia's version
* Deleting/Inserting a new node -> UCS approach 
  In @192 an instructor said that for A* you can use either approach.

James Webb.title: Factoring in FOL resolution
James Webb.text:
Page 347 of Russell + Norvig says that binary resolution is only refutation-complete when paired with factoring (i.e. removing redundant literals in each clause). Redundancy is not as obvious in FOL as it is in PL. For example in the PL clause (A | A), the second 'A' is clearly redundant, thus we can reduce to simply (A). However, what constitutes a redundant literal in FOL? Clearly we wouldn't want to factor something like (F(John) | F(James)), but it seems like we would want to factor (F(x1) | F(x1)). What about (F(x1) | F(x2))?
  More broadly, is factoring even a good idea for HW3 when building our resolution algorithm? Or would that be just asking for much more trouble than it's worth? Should we just stick with resolution of subsets (i.e. n-ary resolution)?
  Thanks for the clarification!

Mason.title: DFS Tie Breaker
Mason.text:
Hello,
  I was looking at this example since it's now added to the test cases in Vocareum and I have a question:
-When DFS is queuing up child nodes, it pushes to the front of the queue, correct?  Since the children nodes for A are given in order: B->C->D, the open queue should look like D->C->B (front->back) after queueing A's children (Because we push_front(B), push_front(C), push_front(D)).  And since D is the last one pushed onto the queue, it will be the first one popped from the front during the next iteration of the search.
In this case, shouldn't the solution be:
A 0
D 1
Z 2
instead?
I realized this is an issue with how the tie breaker is worded:
"If all else is equal while searching routes (ties), you should explore (enqueue) multiple paths from the same intersection in the order in which they are listed in the live traffic inputs."
This can be read as either:
1) Perform the enqueueing function (push_back for BFS, push_front for DFS) on each child as they are ordered from the live traffic inputs   OR
2) Perform the enqueueing function such that the children are in order (from front->back) in the open queue as they are ordered from the live traffic inputs (first->last)
  All of the examples in the hints follow #2, but to me #1 makes more sense to me with how it's worded
This really only affects DFS as it needs to push the front of the open queue which is what the general search function pops.

I don't think it is necessary to update nodes as visited for either UCS or A*.  Since we're looking to achieve the optimal path by way of smallest path cost, marking a node as visited might remove the chance that we find a shorter path involving that node later on.

Therefore, using "and" with "exists" would ensure the condition is satisfied for any number of variables. Hope this helps.

It is because of the ordering of "for all" and "exists". 
  For the order, "exists" and then "for all", you are fixing a particular variable and then checking for all other variables. While checking variables of "for all", the variable in "exists" has to be the same. 
  For the order,  "for all" and then "exists", you fix a variable and check if there exists another variable. Then, repeat over variables of "for all". While repeating, the variable of "exists" need not be the same across iterations.
Once you match y = G(x,x) in the first parameters, the second parameter matching implies y = G(A,B). Since y can take only one value, G(x,x) = G(A,B) which means x = A and x = B. This cannot happen.

shashi kiran yellappa.title: DFS according to hint
shashi kiran yellappa.text:
Hi,
  I have a clarification in the above example given in the hint by the professor. Shouldn't DFS go deep exploring until it reaches and come back only when it reaches a dead end? According to the DFS algorithm the output will be A-B-E-Z. But if we check the presence of a node in queue before inserting into queue we will get it as A-B-Z as explained in the example. Both are straightforward to implement. But I am not sure if checking the queue before insertion is the right way. Could someone help me in understanding this ?

I too agree with @Stephen Hunt. That was my exact point of asking this question. Checking the queue goes against the principles of DFS.
@Sriram: without checking the queue also we can avoid loops by checking the popped element from queue against explored set. If it is already in explored set we just move on. We don't explore that node.

I completely agree with the minimum cost tree we get when we check in queue before adding. I also thought the same way and implemented it. Then when i explored DFS from several places i found out that DFS doesn't care about finding a minimum cost tree. It is the essence of it. It just finds all the nodes reachable.

@Kalham : We haven't visited B C D when we pop A right? We just add B C D to stack. But visit(explore) B first. So explored will contain {A,B} and then children of B and so on. After we reach dead end of B sub tree we trace back and then we visit C and so on. So C is not added into explored(or visited) set until entire B subtree traversed according to the definition of DFS algorithm.
Isn't that a deviation from DFS algorithm? it looks like a algorithm which combines both BFS and DFS to me.

Loop detection can be achieved even if we just check the explored set while exploring a node after its popped from the stack. If its already explored we could just ignore it and move ahead. I am just confused as to which one is the proper implementation. Just want to get a proper confirmation.

Because we haven't yet explored the goal state right? we do the goal test when we remove it from the queue. Here the goal state will be explored via E rather than B if we are following the actual essence of DFS.

Wayne Chi.title: UCS Tiebreaker
Wayne Chi.text:
Two rules conflict for UCS:
  Rule 1:
  "we do not enqueue a node [...] again since we already have one with lower cost in the open queue (loop detection)." - Slide 19 Hw #1 hints
  conflicts with
  Rule 2:
"else if there exists node in open that has child’s state
     if PathCost(child) < PathCost(node)
         open Delete-Node(open, node)
         open Queuing-Fn(open, child)
" - Slide 113 session 02-04 (aka the Clean, Robust, Algorithm)
  If there is a node already in the open queue, should we treat it like a new node as shown in Rule 2, or should we leave it, update its cost, and treat is as an old node as in Rule 1.
  This is important because of this following rule.
Rule 3:
"if all else is still equal, newly expanded nodes should be enqueued after (farther in the queue from the queue's front) older ones that were already in the queue" - Slide 27 HW #1 hints
  Depending on Rule 1 or Rule 2, a node that gets its cost updated may have a higher or lower priority among nodes of the same updated cost.
  Thanks for clarifying.

They conflict because if a node is already enqueued and the cost of it changes, do we not enqueue it again (Rule 1) or do we delete it and enqueue it again (Rule 2). This completely changes the queue time of the node, which will affect the order it appears in the priority queue.

Muye Zhu.title: Tie breaker lower priority rule
Muye Zhu.text:
Hi,
  I'd like to use this very loopy case to see if I'm understanding the tie breaker lower priority rule in Prof. Itti's hw1 hints correctly.
  Enqueue happens as follows:
1. A
2. B C
3. C D (when expanding B, C already in frontier, therefore despite B-> D occur first in input, C is not in the front. but since C is no re-enqueued, its parents still A in path)
4. D E (same reason as 3)
5. solution A -> C -> E
  Correct?... I am quite confused...
if "the parent is based on the travel path", wouldn't DFS exmaple 2 in Itti hint return A->B->E->Z? It seems to me the parent of a node in that example is considered the node that enqueued this node.
starting from D, C is visited first. In live traffic, from the same parent D, C is listed before B.
No. In hw specs: There will be exactly one entry in the Sunday traffic data for each state mentioned in the live traffic data.
when A is reached again as in A A 0, this new optional route does not improve the current known shortest distance to B which is 1. Therefore A shouldn't be enqueued again.

for A->A with non zero cost the node A will eventually have higher cost than other nodes in heap. In your example with A A 0, in condition (1) a simple test to exclude child that has same state as parent is sufficient, since for all intents and purposes to do self loop does not help to solve the problem.
B(y)|~B(y) is tautology, so ( ( B(y) | ~B(y) ) | C(z) ) is always true. I think in this case the clause shouldn't be added to KB, since C(z) can not be inferred.

Archit Srivastava.title: Clean Robust Algorithm
Archit Srivastava.text:
Let's say there is a loop from node A to node A in a graph.
  The algorithm given in the slides indicates that you should
  1. Pop the node from the open queue.
2. Explore children.
    2.1 If the child is in neither(open and closed) queue enqueue the child in the open queue
    .... Other conditions...
3. Put the node in the closed set.
  Considering this, let's say we reach node A from B. A is now in the open queue.
It is popped out of it. Its children are explored (consisting of A).
The child A is evaluated against the condition 2.1. Since A is in neither queue, it is enqueued again and A is marked its parent.
  The node A is now put in the closed set.
  Now A has a self-parent loop while doing the search and loop detection essentially fails for an interim period.

Have I gone wrong somewhere? 
    EDIT:
eg.

UCS
B
C
3
B A 1
A A 0
A C 1
0

Results:
1. B is put in open queue.
2. B is popped out of open queue. A is inserted into open queue and B is marked as parent of A. B is put into the closed set.
3. A is popped out of open queue. Its children A and C are inserted into open queue with costs 1 and 2 respectively and their parents marked as A. A is put into the closed set.
4. A is popped out of the open queue but since it's already in the closed set and its cost is not less than previous, it is ignored. It's put into the closed set.
5. C is popped out of the open queue. Since it is goal, it is returned.
  Now, C's parent is A, but A's parent is again A -> Loop.
I've updated the question with an input. Please check.

The exact pseudo-code described in the slides is as follows:
  currnode  Remove-Front(open)
.
.
.
if no node in open or closed has child’s state ..... (1)
open  Queuing-Fn(open, child)
.
.
.
  When A is popped out of the open queue, it is not in the open or the closed set. It's child "A" will be evaluated against condition (1).
As that is true, A is enqueued again in the open queue and A is made its parent.
The child A node doesn't go to the 2nd or the 3rd conditions for evaluation.

I concede that there should be an additional check in place and the loop will no longer be there or the algorithm should be modified. The pseudo-code in itself, without modifications, will lead to self-loops, that is my only concern.

Hi,

The depth given is 4. So when we compute the value after 4 steps, max value we get is -4. Both C4 Stake and C4 Raid return the same value (-4), According to the implementation mentioned, we consider all Stake moves first and then Raid and since C4 Raid doesn't give us a STRICTLY GREATER value, we go with C4 Stake

Akshay Deshmukh.title: Confusion regarding implementation of UCS and A*
Akshay Deshmukh.text:
I have been reading through threads about the implementations of UCS and A* and I am confused about the version of the algorithm to be used for implementation. Currently, there are two versions of UCS and A*:
  1. The version which updates a node in the Closed set if the child/current node (the node which has been recently dequeued from the Open set for the next pass of UCS/A*) has a cost (f(n)) lower than the node in the Closed set when the current node and the node in the Closed set are equal. This implementation has been given in slide 113 in session02-04.pptx (Clean Robust Algorithm for UCS). This kind of implementation was also demonstrated by Prof. Tejada in one of the lectures for A*.
The graph given above is a reference to the first version of implementation which encounters the given procedure for A*.
  2. In this version, UCS and A* does not check nodes which have been enqueued in the closed set. Once that node is in the closed set, irrespective of the fact that the current node (which is equal to a node in the closed set) may have a lower cost, it is never accessed. This is the standard implementation of UCS/A* which has been given in Wikipedia.
  Which version of UCS/A* is followed in the grading script? I request you to give a definite answer as the grading scheme is harsh.

I will divide my answer in 2 parts:
  1. Consider 2 sets: x \in {A, B, C} and y \in {P, Q, R}.
Now, the FOL sentence correctly translates to "Everyone in the world is loved by at least one person". This would mean that P is loved by B, Q is loved by B and R is loved by A. The interpretation satisfies the universal quantifier constraint on y, as given in the sentence, and the interpretation is considered to be correct.
Your interpretation is "Everyone in the world loves at least one person" which would mean that A loves P, B loves Q and C loves Q. In this case, the interpretation does not satisfy the universal quantifier constraint on y and the meaning has been altered as a consequence. In the given example, R is not loved by anyone and since R \in y, it should be loved by someone in accordance to the FOL statement.
  2. The given statements are general truths (only when blood relations are considered). Such facts hold in all circumstances and universal quantifiers need to be used. When an existential quantifier is used, there will always be a situation which will not conform with English interpretation.
For example, consider this FOL sentence: ∃ x,y,z sibling(x,y) ^ mother(z,x) ^ mother(z,y). Such a statement implies that there are cases where a sibling of a person may not have the same mother as that person. Such a case is not possible in reality (only blood relations) but the sentence implies that such a case can exist. Existential quantifiers imply searching through sets of positive and negative examples and returning a positive instance.
For the next case, consider this FOL sentence: ∃ x,y,w,z FirstCousin(x,y) ^ Parent(z,y) ^ Parent(w,x) ^sibling(w,z). Likewise, this statement implies that there are cases where a child's first cousin may not be the son/daughter of the person who is the sibling of the child's parent. Such a case is not possible in reality (only blood relations) but the sentence implies that such a case can exist.
Universal quantifiers cover all examples in the domain which is being examined. If there is an example which contradicts the universal statement, the statement fails for the entire set. Universal facts are expressed with a universal quantifier. In case of existential quantifiers, the English statement will contain words/phrases which imply a quantity (some, few, etc) which is lesser than the size of the universal set.

If this is unified with clause 5, it will result in L(Tony, Snow). This clause will recursively unify with clause 4. In this case, when do we stop? Like backward chaining, does the actual implementation of resolution refutation keep track of explored clauses?
  Thank you

You can only inherit properties from a superclass

The knowledge bases contain sentences with the following defined operators:
NOT X                ~X
X OR Y               X | Y
X AND Y             X & Y
X IMPLIES Y      X => Y
  It is given in the document.

Vinod Sharma.title: Vocareum submission for Java and C++ using Makefile
Vinod Sharma.text:
To allow arbitrary choice of parsing libraries (supported by Vocareum), submission script will now accept a "Makefile".

If your submission contains a "Makefile", then it must support "run" target so that command "make run" compiles and runs the homework program.

If "Makefile" is not present, then submission script will try to compile and run the program assuming you are not using any external library for parsing.

The following is the content of an example Makefile for Java when using ANTLR for parsing.

#####Makefile Starts#####
run:
        javac -cp .:/home/local/voctools/Java/antlr-4.5.3-complete.jar homework*.java && java -cp .:/home/local/voctools/Java/antlr-4.5.3-complete.jar homework

clean:
        rm *.class output.txt
#####Makefile Ends#####

Note: above Makefile assumes that you have already generated the Java parsing code using ANTLR grammar file and is submitted along with your submission.
  #pin

Did "make run" works on your machine?
  "javac -cp .:/home/local/voctools/Java/antlr-4.5.3-complete.jar Fol*.java"
  Above line only compiles java file starting with name "Fol"
  Compilation of homework.java, Argument.java &  Node.jav is missing from the Makefile. This could be the possible reason.
It's the time limit for a single query in a test case.

The program will be terminated automatically if it consumes more time than allowed. In 10 query case, we allow it to run for slightly more than 300 seconds (For example 350 seconds). Additional time is needed to account for other parts of the homework: for example reading KB and converting it to CNF.

It's best if you spend no more than 30 seconds on each query so that we don't have to terminate the program.

If a code is taking around 40 seconds to run a query, you do not need to worry about it, we will allow a program to run for more than this time. 30 seconds time limit is to stop the badly implemented program from running for a long time.

Pankaj Rajak.title: Doubt in Clean-Robust Algorithm for Uniform Cost search and A*
Pankaj Rajak.text:
As It was said in the lecture sides while expanding  the child node we are following this rule 
1)  If Child is not present in Open and closed set : then add it to open sen
2)  If Child is present in Open set  and its cost is less now :  delete old node and add the child with new cost
3)  If Child is present in Closed set :  then update its  cost ( say node is B and its old parent is A and new parent is C after update due to condition 3 )
  Now my question is in case of  UCF : why do we need the third condition . The solution is always  optimal here using  condition  1 and 2 . Because condition 3 is actually saying you have added a node in closed set whose past  cost is   higher. So here node B will never get added in closed set before  node as path cost from startnode--A is aways higher then pathcost from startnode---C
if                    startnode------A-B > startnode--------C-B 
that means    condition 1  (  startnode------A  >  startnode--------C  and (A-B is smaller then C-B) 
                      condition 2   (  startnode------A  <  startnode--------C  and (A-B is greater then C-B)  
In any case  it will always remove C before A and their is no way B will be added to the closed set . So we dont need condition 3 for UCS
  Question : For A* I agree depending  upon wether you considered  condition 3 or nor  our answer will vary. And I am guessing we are allowed here both version (with and without condition 3 ) for HW1

Suxin Li.title: Filtering example
Suxin Li.text:
Session 25
Slide 35
  Can anyone explain how the value of α is obtained under Day 1 and Day 2?
Day 0:
  P(R0)=<0.5,0.5>
Day 1 (Umbrella appears è U1=true)
  P(R1)=P(r0)P(R1|r0)
    = α0.5<0.7,0.3> + α0.5<0.3,0.7>
    = <0.5,0.5>
  updating with evidence for t=1 gives:
  P(R1|u1)=αP(u1|R1)P(R1)=α<0.9,0.2><0.5,0.5>
       =α<0.45,0.1> = <0.818,0.182>
Day 2 (Umbrella appears è U2=true)
  P(R2|u1)=P(R2|r1) P(r1|u1)
              =α<0.818<0.7,0.3> + 0.182<0.3,0.7>> = <0.627,0.373>
  updating with evidence for t=2 gives:
  P(R2|u1,u2)=αP(u2|R2)P(R2|u1)=α<0.9,0.2><0.627,0.373>
          =α<0.565,0.075> = <0.883,0.117>

In my opinion, because you use Enumeration, the sum of conditional probabilities of all cases is 1. I think alpha is a kind of trick that you can avoid  calculate those probabilities repeatedly. For instance. you need to calculate P(A | b). P(A | b) = P(A b) / P(b) = alpha * P(A  b). P(A  b) = <P(a b), P( ~a b)>  and alpha = 1/P(b). You can calculate alpha by alpha = 1 / (P(a b ) + P(~a b) ). But you have already attained<P(a b), P( ~a b)>, you can just sum them up to get alpha rather than starting from scratch, which might take long time.

The answer is B.
  A literal is an 'atomic formula' or its compliment. You can think of a literal as something that inherently is true (positive literal) or false (negative literal). B is not inherently true or false because we do not know the values of either A or B, there is more 'propositional' structure to B ('and' operation on A,B) where there is no additional propositional structure to A,C,D.

Both x and y are compounds, Op[x] = A Op[y] = B
So go to Unify statement where x = A, y = B
Both x and y are function symbols and they are not equivalent so I go to "else return failure"
This cascades up and the whole thing fails here.

In fact the only time it seems to work is if both sentences have the same number of predicates, the predicates all have the same names, and they are all ordered in the same way. I'm clearly misreading the pseudo code, I'm guessing I'm misunderstanding what is meant by "Compound?" "List?" and how "First" and "Rest" are supposed to work.

    On the first entry of Unify(x = (A(v1,v2) | B(v2,Bob) ) , y = (B(Jack,v3) | (~A(v4,v5))), Theta = {}) It looks like we call the 'If both lists' statement

The inner Unify(x = A(v1,v2), y = B(Jack,v3), Theta = {}) now calls 'If both compound' statement

The inner unify goes to 'Else return failure' because A != B and we work our way back up

Unify(x = B(v2,Bob), y = (~A(v4,v5)), Theta = Failure), again returns failure
The whole thing has failed.

  On the first entry of Unify(x = (A(v1,v2) | B(v2,Bob) ) , y = ((~A(v4,v5)) | B(Jack,v3)), Theta = {}) It looks like we call the 'If both lists' statement

The inner Unify(x = B(v2,Bob), y = B(Jack,v3), Theta = {}) now calls 'If both compound' statement

The inner unify goes to x = y= B return {}
Unify(x = (v2,Bob), y = (Jack,v3), Theta = {}) now calls 'If both Lists'
Unify(x = Bob, y = v3, Theta = Unify(v2,Jack, {})) the inner unify has x = variable, y = constant, so we can call Unify-Var
Unify-Var(var = v2, x = Jack, Theta = {}), neither are in theta already so now we add  {v2/Jack} to theta

Now if both lists returns {v2/Jack,v3/Bob}
Now the previous 'If both compound statement can return Theta = {v2/Jack,v3/Bob}
Now we co back to 'If both lists' with new Theta
Unify(x = (A(v1,v2)), y =(~A(v4,v5))), Theta = {v2/Jack,v3/Bob}), now calls 'If both compound statement'
Unify(x = (v1,v2), y = (v4,v5), Theta = Unify(A,A,{v2/Jack,v3/Bob}))
Inner unify has x = y = A, so we just return {v2/Jack,v3/Bob}

now return Theta = {v2/Jack,v3/Bob, v1/v4, v5/Jack}
return Theta = {v2/Jack,v3/Bob, v1/v4, v5/Jack}

return Theta = {v2/Jack,v3/Bob, v1/v4, v5/Jack}
return Theta = {v2/Jack,v3/Bob, v1/v4, v5/Jack}
return Theta = {v2/Jack,v3/Bob, v1/v4, v5/Jack}

Mark Debord.title: Can you resubmit after deadline?
Mark Debord.text: I have found a major oversight in my code that I think may cause many test cases to fail (although it works on simpler ones). I think I know how to fix it but I likely won't have time tonight. Can we resubmit after deadline (Even if it is for reduced credit?)
It looks like you may have solved this already but here was my process

You can't write it directly. You need to take into account the denominator P(OA) in order to cancel the P(A)
  The picture in the top follow up shows the entire process (note other substitutions can lead to the same answer)

P(xOA) = P(x|OA)P(OA) is also a valid way to start to resolve this.
  The end goal is to get to probabilities that are more easily calculated (or given) by the model. In the little prince example we want to be able to directly use the probabilities given in the tables in slide 3 session. p(x|A) is simply a product series of values from the transition probability tables, and p(O|xA) is a product series from the appearance probabilities. We like these terms because those are probabilities that are more easily measured. The only difficult term in the expression is P(O|A), which is calculable as a dynamic program (forward and backwards procedures)
    If you wanted to start to shape the P(xOA)/P(OA) expression to use p(x|A) and p(O|xA) you could do it like this:
  P(xOA)/P(OA) = P(x|OA)P(OA)/P(OA), simplifying fraction you are left with P(x|OA)
  P(x|OA) = 
      P(OA|x)P(x)      P(O|xA)*P(A|x)*P(x)         P(O|xA)*(P(x|A)P(A)/P(x))*P(x)         P(x|A)P(O|xA)
     --------------  =   ------------------------   =   ---------------------------------------- =    --------------------  <--- this is the expression we were trying to get to
         P(OA)                 P(O|A)P(A)                                P(O|A)P(A)                             P(O|A)
Sorry about the formatting getting messed up I don't know how to edit it (I don't think I even can)

I think the correct is :
  P(+e|+c)=
P(+e,+c)
P(+c)
=
P(+e)P(+c|+e)
P(+c|+e)P(+e)+P(+c|−e)P(−e)
=
0.1×1.0
1.0×0.1+0.1×0.9
=0.5263
  ** The denominator is P(+c) as shown above. You have to expand to P(+c|-e) + P(+c|+e) to sum out 'e' because we are not given P(+c) in the table by itself

Hannes Leipold.text:
Stochastic processes are processes that have to do with probabilities and uncertainty, as you said. A good example is a random walk, because at every point in time, you have a certain chance of going one way or the other. We also include randomness in our simulated annealing, where we make "bad" local moves with an exponentially small probability.
  Nondeterministic processes are those usually used in Computation Theory when discussing Turing Machines. Essentially, nondeterministic Turing machines can do several transitions in one step. A deterministic Turing machine can do only one transition in one step. It matters in terms of NP versus P problems, because it seems some problems can be efficiently solved by a nondeterministic Turing machine and not by a deterministic Turing machines. You can always unwind the nondeterminism (by creating a decision tree and taking every step on the tree), but it will lead (in general) to an exponential time deterministic Turing machine algorithm. Sometimes people say NP problems are those that can be verified in polynomial time, because with a particular path down the tree, it is easy to verify that the answer works.

For each 3x3 block, look at how many are not black. That number factorial is how many choices we have, because we are allowed to exchange any of those states with one another. That is, if we have 5 numbers that are gray, we have 5 slots to place the first number, 4 to place the second number, 3 to place the third number, ... 1 to place the fifth number. This gives you 5!.
  Since this is the case for every block, we have the following math:
  (# of gray numbers in block 1)! * (# of gray numbers in block 2)! * ... * (# of gray numbers in block 9)!
  Filling in for how many gray numbers there are for each block returns the math done by OP.

In the first sentence I think the first part is always false in some models and therefore the implication always true. This is because if there exists any y in our domain that isn't an animal, then the first clause will be false, since not all y are animals. Then for all x in our model domain, the implication will be true. Clearly not what we want the expression to do.

One way to check is just to look at the truth table of two boolean functions. If they match on all inputs, they're literally the same.
In case 1:
000 => 0,0; 001 => 0,0; 010 => 0,0; 001 => 0,0; 011 => 0,0; 100 => 0,0; 101 => 1,1; 110 => 1,1; 111 => 1,1;  so they match
  In case 2:
000 => 0,0; 001 => 0,0; 010 => 0,0; 001 => 0,0; 011 => 1,1; 100 => 1,1; 101 => 1,1; 110 => 1,1; 111 => 1,1;  so they match
  So you can use them interchangeably. Otherwise, you can use inference rules to show that one infers the other and vice versa. From there, soundness of propositional logic shows them to imply one another.

I think by truth table would be the easiest, otherwise you could find a procedure for an inference  and use that \varphi \vdash \psi if and only if \varphi \models \psi for propositional logic (also for first order logic). 
  In general, for \varphi \models \psi you need to check that \psi is true when \varphi is true. If you look at your truth table, you can consider only those cases where \varphi is true and check that \psi is true, but not vice versa.
  If \varphi \equiv \psi then we know that \varphi \models \psi and \psi \models \varphi so you will need to check that for each \psi which is true \varphi is true and for any \psi which is false that \varphi is false. In other words, you have no choice but to look at all entries. If you think these statements are false however, you can just use one clever counterexample where the rule breaks to answer the question.
  If you want to prove satisfiability, you only need to find a clever instance where the truth assignment is true, but if you would like to disprove satisfiability, you would have to check that each value is false. 
  Note that this would be a totally different story for first order logic for formulas that use the forall operator.

Step 8 and 9 are not about forming CNF, but decomposing the CNF into our KB. That is, let \varphi = \psi_{1} \wedge \psi_{2} \wedge \psi_{3} , where each \psi_{i} is a clause. Then it is clear that KB_{new} = KB_{old} \cup \{ \varphi \} = KB_{old} \cup \{ \psi_{1} \wedge \psi_{2} \wedge \psi_{3} \} = KB_{old} \cup \{\psi_{1}, \psi_{2}, \psi_{3}\} since \varphi \models \psi_{i} and \{ \psi_{1}, \psi_{2}, \psi_{3} \} \models \varphi .

Exists x, all y means there exists a particular x, say x1, for which all y is attracted by x1. Then Attracts(x1,_) maps to all of y. 
  However, "for all y, there exists x" means that all of y is attracted by some collection {x1, x2, ..., xn} so that all of y is mapped to, but it might be different x's for each y that accomplish this. So "there exists x, for all y" implies "for all y, there exists x", but not vice versa.

If the statement 
∃x,∀yAttracts(x.y)
is true, then in particular there is some x1 for which
∀y,Attracts(x1,y)
is true. Then in particular
∀y,∃x,Attracts(x,y)
is true, because we have x1. So we have a collection {x1} so that for each y, an item in the collection makes the statement true. Clearly not vice versa, because all we know from
∀y,∃xAttracts(x,y)
is that there is some collection {x1, x2, ..., xn}, but we don't know the cardinality of the set.

E causes C so C happening is correlated with E, but F happening is not correlated with E. The thing is, F happening might cause C to happen, and C happening is correlated with E, but this does not mean F is correlated with E, because, for example, your basket might not be empty because you have an apple or an orange in it, but knowing you have an orange in your basket does not tell you if your basket has an apple. At least this how I understand it, but look at D-separation and independence in Bayesian Networks to understand it better.

This is because the sentences in KB itself are contradicting -
D(John,Bob)
D(x,y) => ~H(y)
G(x)=>H(x)
F(x)=>G(x)
F(Bob)
From the first two sentences we get ~H(Bob) (modus ponens)
From the third sentence we get ~G(Bob) (modus tollens)
And from the fourth we get ~F(Bob) (modus tollens)
And the fifth sentence is F(Bob) - this is a contradiction
So there is an error in the example which must be corrected.

Jinho Park.title: SP2015Exam2-practice 6.4
Jinho Park.text:
4. Which one of the following is not true of ground literals?
a. They have only universally quantified variables as arguments.
b. They behave just like propositional symbols in automated reasoning.
c. They might unify with literals containing only universally quantified variables.
d. They may contain terms that are functions.
  (from PracticeExam2-sol) the answer from is A
  Based on F2016Lecture14-15.pdf page 3
A ground term is a term without variables.
They behave just like propositional literals (i.e. Booleans).
  I believe that the answer is B


I misread the question. A is correct answer.

I agree that the instructors posts in @292 made it pretty clear that Stake actions need to be evaluated before any Raid actions. 
However, it was not so clear that the program is expected to evalue all empty spaces as Stake first (even though the exact same action can also be a Raid) and then evaluate Raid actions. In other words, it was not clearly delivered to students, either by the written homework description nor by the instructors' feedbacks, that the program is expected to pick the best action between Stake and Raid on the same cell by trying both actions.
I believe that this rule (/grading criteria) needed to be clearly stated because this is a counter-intuitive notion. For example, in tic-tac-toe, players do not get to freely choose whether to flip the opponent's piece in the middle or not; it is done automatically by the rule, given the arrangement of pieces.
@Thomas Collins Could you provide an instance of one of the "Piazza questions dealt exactly with this issue" for a reference?

@Thomas Collins. I see that this scenario was specifically mentioned @320. Thanks for the reference.
  The unfortunate fact is that I (and probably other people who did not passed test #15) had not chance to take a look @320. 
  I think that this point was not explicit in the pinned thread @292. It does not mention whether Stake and Raid are mutually exclusive on a single cell or not.
  Now I think that this discussion boils downs to (for myself only other students may have different opinions) ) following two points. (one major and one minor.)
1. whether it was a reasonable assumption to make (i.e. assuming Stake and Raid are mutually exclusive on a single cell). (major point)
2. whether students are expected to be aware of critical information mentioned in non-pinned threads. (minor point)
  Could you re-consider the grading criteria for #15 based on these points?

Mingqi Gu.title: Why B is not right in this unification?

Mingqi Gu.text:
The answer is B.
  A literal is an 'atomic formula' or its compliment. You can think of a literal as something that inherently is true (positive literal) or false (negative literal). B is not inherently true or false because we do not know the values of either A or B, there is more 'propositional' structure to B ('and' operation on A,B) where there is no additional propositional structure to A,C,D.
It is sensible to handle our grades this way!  some of test cases wrong do not mean our program is totally wrong!
we only need to use SUB{x:s, t:John, s:t}

  When talking about resolution, unification is normally done on the predicate level.
For the first example, you missed a step when which is standardizing apart the 2 clauses. Doing so, you should get.
~H(y) | ~D(x,y)
H(a) | ~G(a,b)
Then, Unify(~H(y), H(a)) returns theta={y:a} and using this substitution and cancelling the 2 predicates out, you will get a new clause, ~D(x,a) | ~G(a,b).

Mun Kit Teh.text:
See answer in @302. Use the terminal and run your python file for testing. Eg: homework3.py
Tested and works.

Yes it is correct.
  By resolution, to prove ~H(Alice) first negate the query to get H(Alice)
  The rule D(x,y) => ~H(y) in CNF is ~D(x,y) | ~H(y)
  Using resolution on ~D(x,y) | ~H(y) and H(Alice) by unifying {y/Alice}, we get ~D(x,Alice)
Then, by unifying ~D(x,Alice) and D(John,Alice) with {x/John} we can reach a contradiction.
  As for ~H(John), since H(John) is proven, ~H(John) cannot be TRUE.
  Correct me if I am wrong...

Your problem probably lies in the last sentence given in the KB.
  If you notice, when resolving ~Parent(x,y) | ~Ancestor(y,z) | Ancestor(x,z) with ~Ancestor(Liz,Bob) for example, the resolvent will contain ~Ancestor again.
  Therefore, it might be the case where ur program continuously applies that rule resulting in an indefinite growth of the query.
The output should be in uppercase. TRUE or FALSE.
Its fine. After all, the problem was so trivial... Unless you insist. :P Haha

Guanzhou Liu.text:
The same problem here, I also get the wrong result from test case 3, and I think I need to clarify the problem here:
  First, I have to say it is ok to set stake higher priority than raid in minimax algorithm, because in minimax we get value from fully explored tree. So any equal value we get in minimax is accurate and exact.
  But in alpha-beta pruning, we can't give this priority as we do in minimax. (if we are adhering to the textbook algorithm) In general, our normal alpha-beta pruning algorithm only initialize alpha and beta value once at the root of the tree, which should be -infinity and +infinity. So any later steps will only update alpha and beta value, not initializing them. (here I have to mention this point, because this point is the mainly difference cause the trouble, And I believe lots of students may have this problem if they write their alpha-beta pruning based on their minimax. Because it is easy to write into a different alpha-beta pruning but get same results with test case 3)
  So the different way to do the alpha-beta pruning is that we initialize alpha and beta value every time we get back to depth 1. (in our homework, depth 1 is the step we place our first player on the board)
  Here I will call the normal alpha-beta pruning as #1, and another one as #2.
If we use #1 and #2 both on the same board, we will get different sequence of values at depth 1. Here I will give an example (I think it is also reasonable based on definition):
2
ALPHABETA
X
2
1 2
1 2
..
..
values at depth 1 of #1: -1 0 0 0
values at depth 1 of #2: -1 0 -1 0
  Now lets get back to our homework test case 3
The results of #1:
A5 Stake
..XX.
..XOX
...O.
..OO.
X....
and the values at depth 1 is:
-12 -15 X X -11
-11 -11 X O X
-12 -18 26 O 24
25 25 O O 23
26 26 26 26 23
  The results of #2 is same with test case 3, and the values at depth 1 is:
-12 -16 X X -11
-12 -28 X O X
-12 -46 26 O -31
-35 -28 O O -30
-7 -55 -46 -46 -33
  It is obvious that #2 can give correct answer (I mean "correct" result matched with test case 3), and make me pass every cases provided. But we all know it is wrong, it is not the normal alpha-beta pruning, and it is also not time efficient. 
(Before leaving note here, please check whether you write your alpha-beta correctly)

I say it is wrong considering the time and space complexity. Because the potential time and space complrxity of #2 is way more higher than #1. And the reason we are using alpha-beta not minimax is to save time and space during execution, right. And #2 is totally not implemented as the pseudo code provided in textbook.
I accept #2 is a different way to implement alpha-beta as I described before. So my problem is why using #2. It does not make sense to use #2 implementation because I only want to match the result with test case 3. So if we insist the priority rule in alpha beta pruning, at least test case 3 should give #1 result.

I didn't do prioritizing at any level either, I only did it at the root when I get values at depth 1.

I think the problem is the values at depth 1 are different. (Like test case 3 values from #1 and #2, I also tried to run alpha-beta tree on provided 2x2 example by using #1 and #2) That is why the result is different.
so if F(x, x, y) is available, how to unify it with F(Apple, Pear, Orange)?

Tianyu Fang.title: Question about Translating English to FOL
Tianyu Fang.text:
Consider this example in lecture notes, MW, session 11-12, P29
  "No purple mushroom is poisonous."
  You can translate it in two ways:
¬(∃ x) purple(x) ^ mushroom(x) ^ poisonous(x)   or, 
(∀ x) (mushroom(x) ^ purple(x)) => ¬poisonous(x) 
  But how about using ∃ with => or ∀ with ^? For example, can (∀ x) mushroom(x) ^ purple(x) ^ ¬poisonous(x)
stands for the statement above? Please clarify the differences between them, thanks.

Thank you for your reply. However, with simply change of position of ¬, it seems that the FOL expressions may translate the English statement more closely, which are slightly different from two expressions listed above in my opinion. For example,
  ¬(∃ x) purple(x) ^ mushroom(x) => poisonous(x) means Not EVEN one purple mushroom implies it is poisonous
(∀ x) mushroom(x) ^ purple(x) ^ ¬poisonous(x) means To ALL situations, purple mushroom which is nontoxic is true
Could you please explain detailedly why these two logic expressions cannot translate statement above correctly? Thank you.
Thank you very much, now it's all clear to me:)

I am not sure if i have understood your question correctly. According to my understanding, the question is "If the sentence should stay as 1 sentence or 2 sentence",
then below is the answer.

I think it should stay as 2 sentences in KB.
Lets see how it works step by step:
1. We try to remove implication ----(No implication found, hence sentence stays as it is)
2. Push the negation inside ----(No negation found, hence the sentence stays as it is)
3. Distribute & over |----(In this step, we split the above sentence into two and put each of them into KB separately)

If we don't put it as 2 sentence, then I don't think it will be of any help in doing resolution.

Correct me if you think otherwise.

From what I understand, when resolving two clauses, we are suppose to rename one of the clauses so that the same variable doesn't appear in both clauses. For the following example, I am wondering what is the proper way to do the renaming.
  Suppose we had these two clauses: P(x) | R(z)  and  ~P(y) | Q(z). We would be resolving P(x) and ~P(y), which do not share the same variable name (so no renaming required for them). Do I still need to rename one of the "z" variables, even if they are not part of the literals being resolved? If I don't rename, then the resolvent (new clause) is R(z) | Q(z). If I rename the "z" in the first sentence to "w", then the resolvent becomes R(w) | Q(z). Is it OK for the resolvent (new clause) to have a new variable (in this case, "w") that is not present in the existing KB? Thanks.

  Thank you for your reply firstly!
Yes, with your way B3 is the answer.
But sorry, I'm not totally agree with you. It's just because we can use different tricks on our code. I used an array visited[row][col] to avoid duplicated moves on grid(row,col)[if it was visited, then don't need to visit again]. Because you mentioned that Stake first and then Raid separatelly, I think that the first idea comes to most of students when saw this requirement is to loop over Stake(empty space) first from top-left to bottom-right, and then Raid('X' or 'O') from top-left to bottom-right. Maybe your solution is the better way to avoid duplication, but it's not the ONLY way. It's not FAIR and WISE to say something is definitely wrong!
Also, I think this(the way we use) already involved in the implementation details. It should not be discussed. We are supposed to finish our HW individually.
  Finally, some suggestions for your reference:
1. There is no any official document(lecture slide, HW description) mentioned that all of the things discussed on Piazza are also the REQUIREMENT for HW. It's just mentioned Piazza is a good way to discuss our questions about this course.
  2. I really appreciate the lots of time you guys spend to answer students' questions. But, how to make the time you spend on Piazza more MEANINGFUL?
  Posting a summary for all of additional requirements discussed on Piazza as [Instr Note] to notify every student before deadline(like one week before). [Also it can avoid repeated answers and some similar question]

It's impossible for a student who already finished the HW and is overwhelmed by some other HWs on other courses to go through all of posts and discussions before deadline. We are not taking only one class and we are not supposed to know EVERY student's questions. You mentioned that you modified the instructors answer to that post, maybe only you know that. Students seldom review the posts they saw already.

Same question and I have no idea, but I hope TA will make it is possible. I do not think we can not use C++ because of the platform problem. We can use PLY on python but we can not use C or C++? That do not make sense.

The output of lex and yacc are source files in the language you use, which will be .c files. Do consult the manual for Bison, the GNU implementation of yacc: https://www.gnu.org/software/bison/manual/html_node/Rpcalc-Compile.html#Rpcalc-Compile
According to the spec, the knowledge base is always consistent. There are no contradictory rules.

Please do not use ANTLR. As I remember, ANTLR's generated parser requires you to use antlr.jar with the generated parser, which you cannot do on Vocareum. You can use GNU Bison or JavaCC. For JavaCC, I used this tutorial. A lot of tutorials easily-found on Google are also really bad -case in point, you will need to use syntactic lookahead - please read this FAQ (Section 4.6 "I get a message saying "Warning: Choice Conflict ... "; what should I do?").
All variables are assumed to be universally qualified. So for all x, A(x) is true. Consequently, A(y) is true even if you don't know what y is.
From page four of the spec, they should be two separate lines in your KB

descendant(bob, ross) && descendant(ross, geller) => descendant(bob, geller)

In general yes, predicates can be used to describe transitive relationships.

F(x, x, y) is perfectly valid.Think of the predicate Location(<before>, <action>, <after>) for the Little Prince world for example, Location(x, Turn, x). is true and says that after the little prince turns around, he is still in the same location.
{x/Apple, x/Pear,y/Orange} is invalid, so you fail to unify.
JavaCC produces a standalone parser in 7 *.java files. You can include these with your homework.java file.

Jonathan Gan.text:
I think you can only resolve one pair of literals at a time because you have to ensure that they unify. So resolving 6 and 7, you would choose either

F(x) and ~F(x)
or
H(x) and ~H(x)

So the resolvent would be either

~H(x) v H(x)
or
~F(x) v F(x)

instead of the empty clause.

6 and 7 mean that one of ~H(x) and F(x) needs to be true and one of ~F(x) and H(x) needs to be true. So it is possible to have a world in which, for instance, F(x) is true and H(x) is true, which wouldn't be a contradiction.

Dennis Evans.title: Question about max bounds for predicates, queries, and sentences
Dennis Evans.text:
I am having difficulty deciding how much space I need to allocate to pass the test cases.
The homework specifies:
• Each predicate takes at least one argument. Predicates will take at most 100 arguments.
• There will be at most 100 queries and 1000 sentences in the knowledge base.
  Are these bounds for the text file or during execution of the algorithm?  If they are only for the text file, it really does not tell us anything about the amount of space we must allocate.

Could we also have a bounds for the max # of predicates a sentence can contain?  Without this, the # of clauses in the KB could potentially be infinite after converting to CNF.  Imagine 1000 sentences with 1000 predicates, all & together.
To handle this the KB would have to be able to hold 1000^2 clauses.
Even without such an extreme example, if you have 1000 sentences on the input file the KB could easily grow to an unpredictable factor.

Duc Ho.text:
It should be 0.502. The way I usually do it is i go from the parent down to the one variable in consideration. So first you have no observation/assumptions that is given. You have to substitute 2 values for D0(0.6) and D1(0.4) and multiply accordingly to the table below ( Grade table ). For example : now P(I0,G1) = P(D0)*P(I0,D0,G1) + P(D1)*P(I0,D1,G1) = 0.6 * 0.3 + 0.4*0.05 = 0.2. Now that D is gone, you do the same for I. ,e.g : P(G1) = P(I0)*P(I0,G1) + P(I1)*P(I1,G1) = 0.7*0.2 + 0.3*0.74 = 0.362. Now that I is gone you end up with the last table, do the same.P(L1) = P(G1)*P(G1,L1) + P(G2)*P(G2,L1) + P(G3)*P(G3,L1) = 0.9 * 0.362 + 0.6*0.2884 + 0.01*0.3496 = 0.50234 . (P(G2) , P(G3) is calculated on previous step ).
When you are given(observation is made) like in 2). P(L1| I0). You could cut the row having I1 when calculating P(D0,G1) and P(D1,G1) . Speaking of I1, the table is likely wrong ( Do you see any I1 anywhere, the last two row of Grade table is of I1 variable). Professor please verify slides when you adapt it.
